PS/ Solving complicated w/simplicity is huge value add. Creating complexity+solving it is being an arsonist/firefighter and unsustainable.
11/ Embrace shades of grey but don't solve for them by adding complexity. Some of the world *is* complicated, but make that simple! //EOTS
10/As cudt, engr, mgr, design‚Ä¶ deciding complexity is good, where ur not trading subtlety for complexity, where to push back all critical.
9/ Hard part complexity‚Äîunintended consequences. World knows financial woes. On a smaller scale every day we see self-inflicted complexity.
8/ Sort of a rant. But biz and tech are about nuance. Nuance does not need to also be complex even if the underlying is complicated.
7/ eg. Organization. Start w/hierarchy. Add matrix. Add staff. Add layers. This is complexity that becomes self-defeating or just too much.
6/ eg. Pricing. Cust want discounts. Sales wants empowerment. Result is price where few know what they paid (for) or how much was made!
5/ eg. Features. Pressure to add, yet gain is marginal. But cost in QA matrix, quality, legacy, UX, etc. always increases then overwhelms.
4/ Post is on investing. Same holds for product design, go to market, and more. Trick: know good complexity from bad.  Good actors from bad.
3/ My fav interview question "how does a phone work"? It isn't a trick b/c no one person really knows. Complicated shielded w/ simplicity.
2/ All systems evolve then devolve to a level of complexity that no one can comprehend. Yet, we benefit enormously from complex systems.
1/ Simple vs Complex  https://t.co/IotFo7ffqB by @reformedbroker. Excellent post on two levels. Simple wins! But harder than it looks.

16/So startups looking to BD or M&A ww/Value Co consider this internal dynamic. Understand opex burden, GTM/sales integration, etc. //EOTS
15/Or if there is a fully functioning business that "plugs in" with similar economics and scale, without impacting P&L dramatically.
14/M&A can become easier at such times, but usually only if it does not bring an opex burden. B/C it is off books, if it helps existing biz.
13/Results in efforts loosely connected to core biz/cust. Low risk path. Looks agile. Less internal friction. But seems to lack Value focus.
12/ Esp in enterprise, exact opposite of what you‚Äôd expect which would be to grow biz by offering existing customers more things to buy.
11/Hardest thing to do is spend to bring entirely new product to market serves existing customers with adjacent products‚Äî"line extensions".
10/Managers spend tons energy squeezed between reducing opex and pressure to grow existing biz. Logical that every $ goes to current biz.
9/Even worse, most new innovations are simply used to sustain existing price levels or for S&M for existing rev stream to ensure top line.
8/BUT that is super hard b/c strategy No. 1 is continue to incr revenue. Best way is to increase prices for existing biz. Incr P, Flat Q.
7/Yet at same time every effort needs more $$ but is being pressured to cut. Internal dialogs very tense. Requires super clear strategy.
6/But inside a Company, things are very much a scramble for money. Money money everywhere but not a $ to spend. People, demand gen all flat.
5/That means opex can only go up while maintaining margins, if Co "given" that latitude. At every step Value Investors eyeing abs opex/GM.
4/Except it isn‚Äôt because once a ‚Äúmature‚Äù company is in ‚Äúincrease value‚Äù mode it is also in ‚Äúdecrease opex‚Äù mode. That's the internal model.
3/Note: There's no absolute tradeoff between returning capital and R&D inv. False choice, only at abstract levels does it appear this way.
2/Note, there is a $$ difference in investing in plants/equipment v. software. Much P&E looks like opex now as Mfg is outsourced.

16/My metrics that matter. For apps: what is the usage of the cloud-based service. For plat/infra‚Äîusage of cloud arch. services/APIs. //EOTS
15/Isn‚Äôt definitions/marketing. Internet winners were tech developed for internet, not tech ported to it. Same w/every tech transition.
14/For biz, challenge is margin compression (or raising prices too much). But also missing major shift coming from cloud-first products.
13/For customer, easier, just as sticky as term-based. (Big) risk is just that new cloud-first category killer would have been a better bet.
12/Can be tough b/c on-prem architecture doesn‚Äôt scale super well at cloud scale (multi-ten, storage cost/arch, egress). On-prem ‚â† cloud.
11/What matters for company are margins because of running cloud. Need to tradeoff: balance price increase w/COGS increase for cloud svc.
10/That is good/easier for customers. Many vendors mostly selling their same on prem bits for clients delivered via download+some service.
9/Most ‚Äútransition to cloud‚Äù enterprise activity (per Wall St) swaps out customer capex+opex for higher opex prices for ~same capabilities.
8/Renewal rates were super high b/c of flow of new versions and impossibility of pulling out on prem installations, fear of losing support.
7/All big/mega companies have done software+maintenance for 20 years. Some have sold services along with that. Basically a cloud biz model.
6/On platform/infra/apps/services, most all on-prem enterprise software has been sold as term-based licensing since the late 90s. (i.e. ARR)
5/For platform, architecture matters. Scale up v scale out. Running VMs at remote DC isn‚Äôt ‚Äúcloud‚Äù. Elasticity, app model, etc define cloud.
4/Tricky to divide between apps and platform. Too much cloud dialog over ?aaS that confuses. Platforms get app's features. Apps have APIs.
3/Old meaning of OS, infrastructure, etc. don‚Äôt matter when being commoditized/abstracted by cloud. Can‚Äôt define biz by these‚Äîmisses point.
2/ Loved this attempt to define ?aaS *marketing* terms from National Institute of Standards.https://t.co/Oam7Lg5OG3  Need robustness!
